This project examines the lasting impact of mid-20th century urban renewal policies on Cincinnati's street networks and neighborhoods. Between the 1950s and 1970s, large-scale infrastructure projects—including interstate highway construction and urban redevelopment—fundamentally reshaped the urban fabric of American cities. This website documents what was lost and explores the ongoing effects on connectivity and community.

## About This Project

This work is part of MUSA 5500 at the University of Pennsylvania Weitzman School of Design. The project focuses on Cincinnati, Ohio, as a case study of urban renewal's spatial impacts.

### Data Sources

- **Historical Imagery**: Ohio Department of Transportation (ODOT) aerial photography archive (1946-present)
- **Sanborn Maps**: Georeferenced fire insurance maps showing detailed street networks
- **Street Networks**: OpenStreetMap data via OSMnx
